s:subsection.s:paragraph: The structural package implements a set of primitives for producing technical documentation. The package provides RELAX-NG and XSD schemas describing the format of structural documents and a set of XSLT 1.0 and 2.0 stylesheets for producing XHTML output.

In contrast to other systems such as DocBook, the structural language only defines elements concerning the structure of the document and not the semantics of the elements. The intention is that higher level languages will produce structural documents as output and then use the provided stylesheets to get various services such as table of contents generation, chapter numbering, footnotes, et cetera, without having to re-implement all of those features for each new language.
The canonical format for the structural schema is RELAX-NG, but an XSD schema (generated from the RELAX-NG schema is also provided, for validation using tools that do not support RELAX-NG).

The provided XSLT stylesheets are written in pure XSLT 1.0, with the exception of one extension per XSLT implementation for the purposes of producing multiple output documents from XML source XSLT 1.0 does not support producing multiple documents from one XML source file, requiring the use of implementation-specific extensions. This restriction is lifted in XSLT 2.0, which has a standard element for producing multiple output documents.. A pure XSLT 2.0 stylesheet is also provided, which should be completely implementation independent The package produces both stylesheets from a common source at "compile" time..

As the structural language focuses only on structural elements, it is far simpler than any of the other XML documentation formats. As an example, DocBook, which mixes structural and semantic elements, defines nearly 400 elements as opposed to the 30 or so defined by the structural language.

Given the small number of elements and the relatively strict schema, the number of possible permutations of elements is low and, as a result, the XSLT stylesheets are simple and the XHTML output is easily predictable There are various combinations of DocBook elements that are valid according to the schema but cannot realistically be used due to the resulting XHTML output..
The package has no specific requirements for installation beyond minimal POSIX sh, sed, and make implementations used to process source files to produce the XSLT stylesheets.

Currently, the package requires xmllint and xsltproc to build the optional documentation. The documentation can obviously be built by hand using any XSLT 1.0/2.0 compliant processor; it is just that there is currently no explicit support for this in the Makefile.
To produce the stylesheets, compile the package with the make command: make
Compilation will produce two directories, dist-10 and dist-20.
Optionally, the following command compiles the documentation: make documentation

The structural package is written with the expectation that the files produced by compilation will be copied directly into projects wishing to use it. If the projects in question use XSLT 1.0, files from the dist-10 directory should be used. If the projects in question use XSLT 2.0, files from the dist-20 directory should be used.

The following CSS files should be included in XML projects directly (or more accurately, along with the XHTML output produced by the XML project):
structural-1_0_0-layout.css
structural-1_0_0-colour.css
If the project in question uses RELAX-NG for validation, the file structural-1_0_0.rng should be included. Otherwise, the files structural-1_0_0.xsd and xml.xsd should be included.

Compilation produces two top-level stylesheets per XSLT version. The stylesheet(s) structural-1_0_0-standalone-x{10,20}.xsl produce multi-page XHTML documents as output. The stylesheet(s) structural-1_0_0-single-x{10,20}.xsl produce single-page XHTML documents as output. The single-page stylesheets are essentially considered supplemental to the multi-page stylesheets and this documentation is written in terms of the multi-page stylesheets. Where relevant, the differences between the two are documented.

s:section.s:paragraph:
The XSLT 1.0 stylesheets have been tested and are known to work with the following XSLT processors:
xalan-java version 2.7.1 and above.
xsltproc version 1.1.26 and above.
saxon version 6.5.5.

The XSLT 2.0 stylesheets have been tested and are known to work with the following XSLT processors:
saxon version 9.3.0.4J.

s:subsection.s:paragraph: The "Home Edition" versions of Saxon do not support the extensions required to create multiple output documents with XSLT 1.0 stylesheets. It is necessary to either use the XSLT 2.0 stylesheets with these versions of Saxon, or use a commercially supported version of Saxon.
